newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: AWB Report-Australian wheat market stays strong.
newsitem.headline: AWB Report-Australian wheat market stays strong.

text.p: The cash market for wheat in the Australian state of Victoria remained strong in the past week, propped up by low-volume buying interest, the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) said in its weekly grain market report.
However, triticale and feed barley pricers fell in response to increased supply and in anticipation of reduced dairy demand during autumn/winter, it said.
Sorghum in the state of Queensland continued to move south into Victoria, but prices in Brisbane remained steady over the week at quotes of about A$145.00 a tonne.
The AWB national indicator price moved above the AWB's national pool estimate for the first time this season during the past week, AWB pointed out.
The national indicator is a cash contract fob price offered by the AWB on a delivered port basis and represents the AWB's assessment of the current state of the world market.
AWB wheat shipments totalled 351,069 tonnes in the past week, bringing total shipments this year to 9.96 million tonnes against 6.80 million tonnes in the same period last year.

The AWB confirmed that Egypt had purchased 150,000 tonnes of wheat in the past week, with 50,000 tonnes U.S./Australian wheat for April shipment and 100,000 tonnes of Australian wheat for May/June shipment.
The AWB did not disclose price but said non-AWB sources indicated prices ranged between US$155.00 and US$162.50 a tonne fob for May/June and around $173.00 a tonne for the April tonnage, it said.
